captions.text:
What is reality, knowledge,
the meaning of life?
Big topics you might tackle figuratively

explainIing existence as a journey 
down a road or across an ocean,

a climb, a war, a book, a thread, a game,
a window of opportunity,

or an all-too-short-lived 
flicker of flame.
2,400 years ago,

one of history's famous thinkers said
life is like being chained up in a cave,

forced to watch shadows 
flitting across a stone wall.
Pretty cheery, right?

That's actually what Plato suggested
in his Allegory of the Cave,
found in Book VII of "The Republic,"

in which the Greek philosopher
envisioned the ideal society

by examining concepts 
like justice, truth and beauty.

In the allegory, a group of prisoners
have been confined in a cavern since birth

with their backs to the entrance,
unable to turn their heads,

and with no knowledge 
of the outside world.

Occasionally, however, people 
and other things pass by the cave opening,

casting shadows and echos onto the wall
the captives face.

The prisoners name 
and classify these illusions,

believing they're perceiving
actual entities.

Suddenly, one prisoner is freed
and brought outside for the first time.

The light hurts his eyes and he finds
the new environment disorienting.

When told that the things 
around him are real,

while the shadows were mere reflections,
he cannot believe it.
The shadows appeared much clearer to him.
But gradually, his eyes adjust

until he can look 
at reflections in the water,
at objects directly,
and finally at the Sun,

whose light is the ultimate source
of everything he has seen.

The prisoner returns to the cave
to share his discovery,
but he is no longer used to the darkness,

and has a hard time 
seeing the shadows on the wall.

The other prisoners think the journey
has made him stupid and blind,

and violently resist 
any attempts to free them.

Plato introduces this passage
as an analogy

of what it's like to be a philosopher
trying to educate the public.

Most people are not just comfortable
in their ignorance
but hostile to anyone who points it out.

In fact, the real life Socrates
was sentenced to death

by the Athenian government 
for disrupting the social order,

and his student Plato 
spends much of "The Republic"
disparaging Athenian democracy,
while promoting rule by philosopher kings.
With the cave parable,

Plato may be arguing that the masses
are too stubborn and ignorant
to govern themselves.

But the allegory has captured
imaginations for 2,400 years
because it can be read in far more ways.

Importantly, the allegory is connected
to the theory of forms,
developed in Plato's other dialogues,

which holds that 
like the shadows on the wall,

things in the physical world are flawed
reflections of ideal forms,
such as roundness, or beauty.

In this way, the cave leads to many
fundamental questions,
including the origin of knowledge,
the problem of representation,
and the nature of reality itself.

For theologians, the ideal forms
exist in the mind of a creator.

For philosophers of language
viewing the forms as linguistic concepts,

the theory illustrates the problem
of grouping concrete things
under abstract terms.

And others still wonder whether
we can really know

that the things outside the cave
are any more real than the shadows.
As we go about our lives,

can we be confident 
in what we think we know?
Perhaps one day,

a glimmer of light may punch a hole
in your most basic assumptions.

Will you break free to struggle
towards the light,

even if it costs you 
your friends and family,

or stick with comfortable
and familiar illusions?
Truth or habit? Light or shadow?

Hard choices, but if it's any consolation,
you're not alone.
There are lots of us down here.

title: Plato’s Allegory of the Cave - Alex Gendler

comments.author: Katz Pajamas

comments.text:
Finally there is a great video that explains the Allegory of the cave well! 
I have had difficulty finding a good video so I created my own Allegory of 
the Cave in Lego. I took several pictures and turned that into a Power 
Point Presentation. I use this presentation to show my students the 
difference between perception and truth. I take them through the story as 
the video here does and at the end I ask my students, what character(s) do 
you think you are? Then, I ask, what character(s) do you think I am? The 
students reply by saying that they are the two other prisoners chained to 
the rocks and that I am the one that was freed and saw all the new stuff. I 
do this because I teach in an inner city school where the students don't or 
won't believe my or other teachers when we say that education is important. 
They feel that they can just get by with a D and it will be OK. Without 
going into the many reasons for this, I feel that I am able to connect with 
my students and they still don't fully believe me. This is a human response 
to all aspects of social life, which is why we still discuss this allegory 
today. The intent or point of view needs to be amplified to a degree were 
the person cannot make comparisons greater than the new information being 
shown. This means that the nascent information must be of greater mental 
volume, greater affinity with other ideas, or have a higher mental 
resolution than opposing ideas. This is what had occurred with the prisoner 
that was freed. To be able to transfer information in a believable manner 
these three criteria must be included. I use Legos to teach scientific 
concepts. It allow me to deliver a concept easily because there is a high 
mental resolution and a great affinity with other ideas that they already 
have  or have been shown recently with videos or pictures. ﻿

comments.text:
I wrote a poem about Plato's Cave.

“You think you’re alive but you’re in Plato’s cave
Bound and shackled, a corporate slave
Work your day for a worthless wage
Buy shit you don’t need to decorate your cage
Or break your chains
Take up the fight
Let yourself be blinded by the light
Ascend with me to see the sun
So I don’t have to be the only one”﻿

comments.text:
Why does religion have to be illusion and the absence of truth? The only 
illusion is the one we allow ourselves to swept away with. The idea that 
there can only be two sides to an argument is ignorant and selfish. The 
only goal in this way of thinking is finding the next debate to win instead 
of findings solutions and compromises!! Religion is NOT useless! Many of my 
morals in life are good hearty ones that come from my Sunday classes as a 
child. But there are also some things that I don't agree with that I hear 
during sermons! I see a world full of blind mindless drones believing 
whatever they're told or vice versa, questioning everything accepting 
nothing!! How can anyone grow their mind like this? Never moving on or 
never grasping onto anything solid?! Subconsciously blaming organizations 
instead of looking at situations and what is inside them. Doing Research. 
Being Informed. Trusting Neighbors. Questioning what is Agreed Upon. How 
can anyone live without smelling, seeing, or appreciating the freakin' 
Roses? ﻿
comments.author: KayskolA

comments.text:
+Leo Blight of course once any form of religion is mentioned everyone 
becomes blind to their own perceptions and are then close minded to the 
deeper meanings that are trying to be portrayed. This, however, is also two 
sided: those who see only what they want when it comes to their beliefs are 
also blind to the world and the true grayness of reality. And beliefs, to 
be more broad, can relate to anything from religion to politics to diets to 
child care. Why is it a sin against society, especially American society, 
to believe what you want? If you have put yourself in an environment with 
someone who is not afraid to speak openly about what they love then you are 
the one who should attempt to rethink. I would also like to make the point 
that this comment is not directed at the person tagged, rather, became a 
gentle plea with only God know who.﻿

comments.author: wetraerwegt

comments.text:
I just learned about this in my Classics class so let me clear up some 
confusion: the cave was originally deep underground and other people cast 
"shadows" using puppets and a fire behind the prisoners (which represents 
our Sun). Now I'll break down what everything in the cave represents.
Let's use a chair for our example.
The "shadow" is simply the picture of a chair i.e a visual representation 
of what a chair is. The puppet acts as the chair in the real world. On the 
surface the reflection of the chair (in water for example) acts as the 
definition of the chair, while the actual chair itself represents the idea 
of a chair (with an understanding of good since the "real sun" represents 
Goodness aka the source of everything).

I hope that cleared up some confusion ^u^﻿

comments.author: Glenn Easterling

comments.text:
Note how philosophers in this allegory both gain and lose something; while 
they gain knowledge and wisdom, they lose their connection with the 
"cave-people" and the ability to convey their views and knowledge to them. 
So the allegory isn't all flattery for the wise and enlightened, which I 
think is a good thing.﻿

In the translations I've read, the light actually comes from a fire, and 
from figures (the guards) who make shapes in front of that firelight to 
cast the confusing shadows on the wall. So the prisoners are actually 
another step removed from the actual light of the sun. I don't know what 
the actual Greek says, though.﻿

comments.text:
I've heard this allegory used both for and against religious views:
Atheistic views say this allegory is about science being the enlightening 
force, and that the religious stay ignorantly in the cave.
Religious views say that God, or any other supernatural force is 
enlightening, that there are things beyond human perception. Entirely 
trusting our senses, in this argument, is seeing the shadows on the cave 
wall.﻿
